hints_html:
Recall that an eigenvector is a vector such that, left-multiplying it by A produces a multiple of itself, i.e.,

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}.\end{aligned}\]

Do you see this property in the provided vectors?
hints_raw:
Recall that an eigenvector is a vector such that, left-multiplying it by A produces a multiple of itself, i.e.,

:<math>
A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}.
</math>

Do you see this property in the provided vectors?
question: B 03 (a)
sols_html:
From the hint we recall that an eigenvalue, eigenvector pair satisfies,

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}.\end{aligned}\]

We have in our problem that [1,1] transforms to [2,2], which in matrix form is,

\[\begin{aligned} A \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix} = 2 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we see that [1,1] is an eigenvector of A with eigenvalue 2. For the other case we have that [1,-1] gets transformed to [0,0]. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} A \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = 0 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and so we see that [1,-1] is also an eigenvector with eigenvalue 0. Recall that an \(n\times{n}\) matrix has at most n eigenvalues. Therefore since in this case, n=2, we have found all the eigenvalues of the system. We conclude that A has eigenvalues and eigenvectors,

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_1&=2,\quad{}\mathbf{x}_1= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\\ \lambda_2&=0,\quad{}\mathbf{x}_2= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
From the hint we recall that an eigenvalue, eigenvector pair satisfies,

:<math>
A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}.
</math>

We have in our problem that [1,1] transforms to [2,2], which in matrix form is,

:<math>
A
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
2
\end{bmatrix}
=
2
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Therefore we see that [1,1] is an eigenvector of A with eigenvalue 2.  For the other case we have that [1,-1] gets transformed to [0,0].  Therefore,

:<math>
A
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
=
0
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and so we see that [1,-1] is also an eigenvector with eigenvalue 0.  Recall that an <math>n\times{n}</math> matrix has at most n eigenvalues.  Therefore since in this case, n=2, we have found all the eigenvalues of the system.  We conclude that A has eigenvalues and eigenvectors,

:<math>
\begin{align}
\lambda_1&=2,\quad{}\mathbf{x}_1=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\\
\lambda_2&=0,\quad{}\mathbf{x}_2=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}.
</math>
statement_html:
Let A be a \(2\times{2}\) matrix which transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A?
statement_raw:
Let A be a <math>2\times{2}</math> matrix which transforms

:<math>

1

</math>

and transforms

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}

-1
\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A?
